The edge of the paper deviates from the latitude because you re-orient the sheet of paper by pressing it against the surface of the globe. (This is the reason we have Mercator projections.) Instead, shape the paper into a cylinder whose circumference matches that of the line of latitude. Now lower the cylinder over the globe. Now you have a straight edge that parallels the equator at every point.
you must be very popular around guys

Hey that paper over globe is misleading: when you try to shape the paper onto the globe you curve it and that's why it curves away from the latitude line. Now try it like this: pinpoint one corner of the paper to the latitude line and grab any other corner of the paper and trace it along the latitude line until the paper is stretched out. Well now suddenly it is a "straight line". But only the edge of the paper is touching the globe. It all comes down to what plane your viewpoint is perpendicular. If you're perpendicular to the surface of the Earth (aligned with the direction of gravity) than walking in a "straight line" will always result in you going around the Earth at the greatest circumference (in any direction). But if you change the inclination relative to the Earth's surface then walking in a "straight line" results in a different path. So "straight line" in this demonstration is actually RELATIVE and thus your example is misleading.

Ok so I wanted to add a couple of things. First of all, remember that I am no astrophysicist and secondly, I have no references, so take it as you may will. A black hole is also called an invisible singularity. Singularity why? Cause it is one object that breaks the laws of physics (or doesn't, we just don't know it yet). Light cannot come out of a black hole, not because of gravity (photons do not have mass), but because of the curvature of space-time itself. Think of it like a bottomless well which once you start falling inside, you will fall forever. Now what happens in reality is that any object nearing the event horizon, start going forward in time (yes that is relativity for you), for the observer, it seems like the object is slowing down (even though the gravity is increasing with decreasing distance). This is because any matter in the universe exhibits gravity based on its density, the higher the density, the higher the gravitational attraction. Now why is this important? Cause these large celestial bodies actually curve space time in a way such that the rate of flow of time decreases the closer you are to a body with high gravitation. So for example, the Sun which has higher density than the Earth, experiences a decrease in flow of time relative to Earth. A black hole is an entity where the space time curvature is so much that because of this property, the rate of flow of time reduces exponentially as you move towards the event horizon. That is why objects falling into the black hole (while you can see them) will seem like they are falling indefinitely. Now at the event horizon, these objects that fall in, from the observer's point of view, the objects get stuck in time forever. So when you consider light, its not because of gravity that the light cannot come out of the event horizon, but its literally because for us, the light or whatever object that has fallen inside the black hole are literally frozen in time. Thus, the objects form a layer on the outskirts of the black hole (which we cannot see) but are present in a squished sort of way, thus preserving the theory that information cannot be lost. Now for the objects that fall in (they are no longer objects anymore but destroyed into elementary particles like atoms or quarks), we don't know what happens from their point of view, cause from their point of view, time flows regularly and at the same time they are inside the event horizon. Black holes grow in size the more matter they consume and this can be observed. There is one theory that states that as black holes grow in size, they will ultimately merge into one huge black hole, which can form another universe inside it. Black holes are the only objects in the universe that defy laws of physics. That is why I think that if this universe is a simulation, that is probably a bug in the code of this simulation.

Thumbs up for the illustration of the point that gravity, as described by GR, is not a force. There's a lot of fixation even among physicists on gravity as a force, hence as a (fundamental) field theory.
On the matter of what BH's are, first of all they are certain solutions to GR equations, which yield certain consequences such as that there's an event horizon from which nothing escapes.
We somehow get the picture that things fall in and are "lost" to us, or rather the BH (its properties) is all that is left as physically accessible to us. In a sense what is accessible includes the proximity of its event horizon, though properly this is still the "outside universe" (relative to the BH).
But is the "sink hole" the right picture? When things fall into the BH, when they reach its event horizon?
For any reference system of the outside universe, not at any finite time: it takes an infinite amount of time for something to be seen as falling in. The picture that is given and objective to the outside universe is that of energy-matter accumulating on this side of the event horizon.
This "seeing" that we are talking about is not simply appearances, they are objective relations under general-relativistic laws. When we determine a distribution of energy-matter to put into the GR equations, it is in the very same sense as we are now speaking of "seeing".
We started by saying that BH's are certain solutions to GR equations, but these solutions, via the equations, corresponds to energy matter distributions. Proper theoretical BH solutions have infinite density at the singularity inside the event horizon. You can get to that by considering a fixed energy-mass and progressively reduce the volume it occupies. But this is not a physical process, it is an analytical path through a set of solutions of GR. At some point we get an event horizon, and the consideration that this has the property that nothing falls in renders the analysis we were following suspect, at least in view of describing physical BH's.
We do know that the solution for an energy-matter distribution outside of the event horizon is not the same as that of an infinite density at the singularity. Furthermore if no energy-matter is inside the event horizon, we would not have a well defined solution inside of it (where there is no energy-matter, GR doesn't have a unique solution). Einstein though that these multiple solutions would represent the same physics, I think this scenario suggests the possibility that simply geometrodynamics is not defined where it is not well defined: there is no inside. And this latter point makes physical sense to the outside universe for the very fact that it sees nothing getting in.
A physical black hole might not be described by the traditional proper theoretical BH solution, with an inside and a singularity, rather by a solution considering that energy-matter is accumulated on this side of the event horizon. Then, the picture is not that of a sink-hole, but that of a geometrodynamical cavitation: what is cavitating due to high energy-matter density is the very geometry of spacetime. And we probably shouldn't think that there is an inside (well defined to the outside universe), we have no reason to think that the geometry of spacetime is embedded in any other extension, curvature is intrinsic, and in the cavitation scenario it does not extends to the other side of the horizon.
The benefits of this scenario are:
- it fits the idea (it is based on it) that it takes an infinite amount of time to "see" anything fall into a BH, more precisely, to this universe nothing falls into the event horizon, rather it accumulates on this side of it,
- there is no singularity,
- there is no information loss,
- makes sense of the result that BH entropy is a function of the area rather than the volume.
The cons: I don't know if it is right. :P

Academia is incorrect with regard to many points; This include Einstein and Hawkins and Feinman and many others. Kudos, indeed Physics girl for regurgitating eloquently that which most of us have been taught. I mean it: wonderful presentation! The challenge with theoretical physicists is they live in a world of Unicorns whereas theories become models that have no basis in actual workings. The regauging of equations by adding constants is but one example. We end up with theories that only work at the macro scale and necessitate another one for the micro scale.We consider theories that throw away 96% (give or take) of the Universe, simply because we cannot yet observe it. We confuse attributes of things for the thing itself. My hand waving is still my hand. Waving is that which my hand is doing. A wave does not exist in and of itself. Something must exist, in order to wave, whether that something can be perceived, or not. We invent virtual particles for the sake of making equation work. We take all those things for gospel and current science is now more dogma than actual genuine science. A few succeed in breaking away from academic science and actually use thought, logic, intuition as well as retroduction to arrive to true understandings. Observations and explanations are two vastly different animals, unfortunately too often confused by scientists.What is energy? What is light? What is a field? The words we use must explain the phenomenon and not merely describe it, and the mathematics must also explain the phenomenon; not make up a model. It may not be simple to explain, but it can be simplex. Ken Wheeler certainly attains that level of understanding, even if his delivery is not always tasteful. See, also Nassim Haramein. I like those rebels of science that do not abide by the indoctrination of Academia and cannot stand the "dumification" of Humanity through a system that does not condone thinking and the scientific method, but that rewards regurgitation of ideas and dogma as basis for more of the same. One of the biggest criticisms of black holes I've heard is that, since time slows exponentially as you approach a black hole (from our frame), nothing can actually reach the event horizon. I've heard a lot of responses to this, but nothing consistent or particularly convincing. I've heard people say that only primordial black holes exist (from the big bang), for the same reason - gravitational time dilation prevents stars from fully collapsing the same way it prevents objects from reaching the event horizon. Others say that since our frame is relative, and the object flying into the black hole would definitely not see itself as "frozen in time" (like we see in our frame), it does actually get into the event horizon... but this would take literally forever in our frame. This doesn't mesh with the idea of Hawking radiation either, which predicts the black hole would eventually evaporate.

In 1973–75, Stephen Hawking and Jacob Bekenstein showed that black holes should slowly radiate away energy, which poses a problem. So if the 'soft hairs' are at a distance M from the center of the black hole (the Schwarzschild radius), then their world lines must point straight away from the center for them to 'stand still' at a distance of M, i.e., heading away from the BH at c while the inrushing spacetime collapses at c. Any other geodesic would spiral into the BH. For all of the information contained in an object that falls into a BH, how does all of that info get coded into photons with this unique and crucial radial 'bundle' (if you will) of world lines? If the object were the nucleus of an atom, the relative motions of the constituents (protons and neutrons) would, in effect, have a distribution of world lines about a common world line trajectory (think, for example, of the Earth and Moon's orbits around the Sun -- they aren't perfect ellipses since the Earth and Moon orbit each other around a common centroid), so how can all of the information of the subatomic particles in this nucleus get encoded into soft photons? And what I wrote assumes a straight world line directed towards the center of the BH, not an object (nucleus in my example) with a non-perpendicular entry through M.

Nobody every seems to ask the pertinent question about Black Holes: If Space is curved, then Time is too, which we know, but what temporally happens to the Black Hole due to this curvature?


A Black Hole is a Star, rapidly (from it's own PoV) converting it's mass into energy, as photons. Once the collapse begins, it tries to force the mass to compress further, but it can't; it's already degenerate matter. Instead, it's converted to pure energy, in the form of photons. The collapsing shell of degenerate matter keeps the photons bottled up inside, until all the degenerate matter has been converted, then it explodes as all the contained photons can get out.


That's what the Star sees.


What WE see is that the Star has collapsed beyond it's Schwarzschild Radius and nothing that falls in will ever come out. But that's not accounting for the warping of spaceTIME.


Here's what you'd see if you fell into a Black Hole and could withstand spaghettification: As you approached the Black Hole, your clock would slow down, but you wouldn't see that, you'd see the external Universe's clock *speed up*, you'd ALSO see the Black Hole's clock speed up. The Event Horizon would shrink, faster and faster as you got deeper and deeper, until it was speeding away from you at, what to you, seems like the speed of light, until it explodes in front of you as a GRB and you die, trillions of years in the future of the point in time you left from, and wherever in space the Black Hole got gravitationally flung to in the meantime.

If my understanding is correct, nothing actually ever enters the black hole.
Relativity tells us that the faster we move or the stronger the gravitational field we are in is, the slower time flows relative to the rest of the universe.
Time is dilated by such an extent at the event horizon that it has come to a complete stop. If that's the case, then nothing can get past the event horizon, because nothing has actually reached the event horizon yet.
When we look at a black hole from the out side we see a 3 dimensional sphere enclosing a volume of space. But this is not what is actually there. What we see is an illusion caused by the effects of Relativity.
There is nothing, not even space, inside a black hole.
If we were to attempt entry (attempt, because we can't actually get to the event horizon) we would need a ship strong enough to withstand the tidal forces and a massive blast of radiation. But assuming we take Neil's Spaceship of imagination (because it looks cooler than Sagan's) as we got closer and closer to the event horizon our former friends will watch us just fade away as our time is more and more dilated.
Time will go slower and slower relative to the rest of the universe, until we reach the point where the black hole evaporates completely.
As a stellar mass black hole will not evaporate completely for more years than we have a name for and possible beyond the age where proton decay erased all the matter, we will be moving at nearly the speed of light, but we won't see much because there will be no stars and no stuff to see in any case.
Black holes are time machines giving us a one way ticket to the end of the universe!
